Concept of Countability in Algorithms



COUNTABLE SETS

Any infinite set is called countable or countably inifinite set if we can find a bijection f: N -> S, from the natural numbers to set S.

Theorem : The set of finite length bit strings {0,1}* is countable.
PROOF : We can easily create a bijection from natural numbers to binary strings just by mapping the decimal form to binary form. And hence we can easily see that the binary relation is formed here and hence the finite length bit strings {0,1}* is countable.


UNCOUNTABLE SETS

Any infinite set is called uncountable if we cant establish any bijection relation between set of natural numbers and the given set.

Theorem : The power set of bit strings P({0,1}*) is uncountable.
PROOF :

  • Lets define function f(x):{0,1}* -> {0,1} such that for each subset S of the set P, we will define it with a binary string such that value 1 for the elements present in the set and value 0 for elements not present in the set.
  • Now lets assume that set P is a countable set, then we can list all the binary language as a sequence L1, L2, L3, L4 ..... supposedly containing every language of bit strings.
  • If we list them in a table then we can easily see that we can use Cantor's diabolical diagonal property to create one such binary string using the diagonal elements of the table such that it does not exist in the bijective relation table. And hence we found atleast one binary string in set P which cannot be mapped to natural numbers using any bijective relation. And hence the set P, power set of the binary strings is uncountable.


CONNECTION TO COMPUTING

Theorem : There are computational problems that computer cannot solve.
PROOF :
  • We simply have to show that there are more computational problems than computer programs.
  • We very well know that every computer program can be represented as a binary string and hence the set of computer programs is countable.
  • But since we know that problems are membership queries in languages hence the set of all problems has the same cardinality as the P({0,1}*), and since the power set is uncountable it is clear that number of computational problems are more than computer programs and hence there exists atleast one computational problem which cannot be solved using computer program.


CHURCH TURING HYPOTHESIS

According to this hypothesis algorithms are described as nothing but, the turing machine.
  • Machines are not omnipresent :It takes non zero time to retrieve data from far off locations. Because, very large memories are inherently sequential.
  • Machines are not omniscient : Only finite information can be stored/retrieved from finite volume because, of finite set of tape symbols.
  • Machines are not omnipotent : A finite length code only exerts finite amount of control, because only finite set of control states can be loaded in finite tape of symbols.


TURING MACHINE -- SIMPLEST PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE

We can say that turing machine is the most simplest form of algorithm representation. Turing machine mainly consists of 7 Tuples.
